text: Gold brown clear. Smells like dull hopped lager. Probably more like a IPL in taste. A logger lager for somebody who like bitter IPA hops. Perhaps just a tad of vienna in there. Near 6% and it never lets you forget.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Bottle - big foamy head, clear medium copper color, good balanced aroma and flavor with caramel bread malt and earthy/piney hops, not bad overall 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

copper clear light amber. Foamy. Sweet rich caramel nose, with fruits. Some spices. The caramel aroma is real nice for a mostly caramel aroma. Not really getting the grapefruit pine.NIce amber lager overall.
Bottle - Pours a medium amber, soapy head. Malty and piney balance. Caramelized malts/fermented dark bread, toffee, woody, some roasted nuts, rich hops background, with a floral yet fruity overtone.

Bottle, single from my local Maverick. Pours a stunning copper orange color with a thick and creamy beige head. Lots of lacing throughout the glass. Pine and light bits of citrus in the aroma as well as lager malt. The taste is bitter, but modest. Some sweet bready and lager malt tones. A little bit of grapefruit. Overall pretty decent session brew.
Bottle from Smiths. Pours clear and deep copper with off-white head. Nose is caramel malt, pine, hops, grapefruit. Tastes caramel malty, hoppy, with notes of pine and grapefruit.
Poured from a 12 OZ bottle into a pint glass. The appearance is a clear amber brown color with a small white head. The aroma is malt and mild hops. The taste is similar to the nose.
Taste: a crisp hop, meets just enough malt to make a balanced amber lager. A bread, zesty nose. Reddish copper color, clear, with a delicate foam of head and ringed lattice. Medium body.

12 ounce bottle. Clear copper, large foamy white head, good retention. Aroma of pale malt and a bit of grapefruit. The taste is toffee, caramel, pine, grapefruit. Medium bodied, lingering bitterness. 100th Vienna Lager!
On tap at Capones. Poured an amber color with a small sized off white head. Citrus, pine and some toast.

Bottle poured into a lager glass. Clear copper color with a sudsy white head and lots of visible carbonation. Aroma is grapefruit, caramel malt. Initial taste is pine hops, very light citrus. Very crisp and clean. Aftertaste is much the same with a lingering bitterness. Light palate that works for the style. A nice, easy drinking beer.

12 oz bottle. Pours amber with tall, long-lasting, fluffy white head. Aroma is of grassy hops and caramel and biscuit malt. Body is medium and crisp. Herbal hops and bready malt fill the mouth. Finish is long and bitter. They shouldve used different hops.
12 ounce bottle. Pours a clear reddish brown with a decent off-white head. Aroma of malt, citrus, and pine. Taste is caramel malt, citrus, and pine. Very average.
12 oz. bottle. Poured clear amber with white head. Aroma was bread, pine, caramel. Taste was mild bitter, earthy, hops, caramel malts.

12oz bottle pours a clear amber/orange with a large khaki head. Aroma of caramel and toffee malt with butterscotch. Taste of honey bread and grain, caramel and toffee, with an all encompassing dry hop bitterness, light pine searching for grapefruit. Awful aroma, bitter hops save the taste. An ok amber lager.

Pours clear amber with a finger of off white head. Aroma is eatery with some caramel malt. Flavor is more sweet malt with esters and light hop.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Not what I expected, better than expected. Pretty nice amber lager. Mildly sweet caramel flavors, not very hoppy (not really getting the grapefruit and pine mentioned in the commercial description). Clean, balanced.
Looks smells and tastes like a watered down IPA. Probably the ideal starter craft beer for those who want to try IPAs.

On tap at Ellyns Tap & Grill in Glen Ellyn, IL., and dispensed to a shaker displaying a clear & bright, amber/copper color, with a fluffy layer of off white foam, and curtain-like cling to the lacing. The nose was some bready malt, hints of caramel, vanilla, straw, & banana, slight spicy phenols, and a touch of citrus. The taste was similar, medium bodied, with good carbonation, adding a lingering earthy & resinous bitterness that was a little aggressive for the style. Finished crisply, and a decent grill complement.

Pours a dark ruby color with a fairly large white head. Weak aromas of grass, bread and some citrus. Pleasant flavors of tropical fruit, citrus, bread dough, hay and some caramel malt. The flavors come together nicely with a slightly bitter finish. This is an interesting take on the traditional Amber and Id say it has been successfully pulled off.

12 oz bottle pours a clear copper color with medium off-white fluffy head. Aroma has bread, molasses, grapefruit, and pine resin. Taste is slightly sweet with a hoppy, dry finish. Body is light to medium with average carbonation and a crisp mouthfeel. Im generally not too fond of Amber Lagers or big breweries, but this one was refreshing, easy to drink, cheap ($4.99 per 6) and much more satisfying than expected. Well balanced and a bit different.

3/18/2017: Goose Island Preseason Lager pours a beautiful copper color. Aroma is lighty hoppy along with some nutty bread; flavors include dried leaves, lightly toasted malt, caramelized yellow grapefruit (but not sweet), slightly sour and a definitely fruit that I cant really call out by name, slightly dry in the finish. Overall, this is a hoppier Vienna Lager than one would expect for the style, but the flavor profile works well. Dumb name, but really good beer.

Bottle. Amber body with off-white head. Aroma of toasted grain, bread, caramel, grapefruit and light pine. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Sweet to start but slightly sour in the finish. Lingering light pine taste.

Tap at Woodies. Brilliantly clear reddish orange color. White foamy head. Malty aroma. Sweet caramel notes. Sweet malty flavor, dry notes, caramel flavor, dry bitter hoppy character. Finishes bitter. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12 oz bottle pours golden with a white head. Aroma of citrus, pine, grass and some caramel. Taste is malts and grains with a little citrus.
Pretty good beer. Not my favorite Amber lager but a good one and a style I like.

Pour is a crystal clear amber with a large white head. Aroma is a nice mild pine hop with a slight malt sweetness. Flavor is pine hop with a nice chewy malt backbone. Quite bitter even for a hoppy lager. Nothing wrong here. A thin lager malt body with a pretty decent hop bite.

Aroma is bready, rye, pine, citrus, cereal, metallic. Appearance is amber, light light tan head, clear. Taste is bready, citrus, pine, rye, cereal, grainy, its really really nice. Mouthfeel is light body, light crisp carbonation, pine and bready malt aftertaste. Overall, this is solid.

Bottle, I think from Kroger. Pours amber with a small frothy white head. Grass, brown leaves, light smoke, caramel in nose. I smell zero grapefruit and pine as the description suggests. Flavor is piney, with lots of caramel malts, some burnt sugar, light orange. OK, but not worth writing homeabout.
Bottle. Caramel malt, fresh hay, and orange peel aroma. Dark amber with large tan head. Moderately sweet caramel malt and mild bitter vegetal and grass flavor. Good body. Decent.

Im not sure what they are going for w/ this but it kind of tastes like a brewpub amber circa 2003. So thats not great. It has a muted fruity hop character, its too sweet and the finish is loaded w/ sticky, woody bitterness. Theres an interesting bubblegummy stressed-yeast malt-liquor character floating over the top as well. If you are one of those people who complains about the state of craft beer these days, go take a step back in time, drink this and shut the fuck up.
Pours clear amber with low white head. Aroma of bread, citrus, malt. Taste is initial bread sweet followed by a bitter finish. Light and smooth body with average carbonation.

Pour from a 12oz bottle. Clear amber brew with tan head. Nice aroma of sweet malt, grass, some toasted malt notes. Taste is moderate sweet malt up front, emerging grass and nutty notes in the middle, ends with grass and lingering caramel sweetness. A nicely executed Vienna style lager. I didnt pick up the grapefruit and pine referenced in the description but dont miss it. Nice spring lager.
Pours a clear amber with a nice off white head. Aroma is both nutty and grassy. Taste is sweet caramel malt, buttered crackers and some grassy hoppiness. Simple and very good!

Sampled on draft at Tapped this beer poured a caramel-tan color with a medium sized foamy orange-white head that left good lacing. The aroma was faintly toasty and malt with light sweet fruits. The flavor was sweetish and tangy with a bit of caramel, crisp fruity hops and a bit of sour mash. Medium length finish. Medium body. Solid.
Pours a clear golden orange from the bottle with fluffy white head that dissipates to leave light lace. Aroma and taste of mild citrus and lager yeast. Not what the label days, but not bad.

Draft to pint at Bent Rail. Looks good for the style; a transparent copperish orange with foamy off-white head. Smells of bitter and piney hops and mild lager yeast alongside a bit of caramel and a hint of toast. Tastes like it smells with a pleasantly bitter medium-bodied mouthfeel. Good and sessionable.
Clear amber pour with a beige head and good retention. Decent lacing. Smooth and clean mouthfeel. Solid caramel malt body with a light hop finish. Crushable. 5.8 ABV is undetectable.
nice malty aroma. amber and clear in color with decent head. taste is of malty of medium caramel malts. hope notes are piney

On tap at 109 Brews. It poured an amber color with a white head. The aroma was of caramel, bread, pine and citrus. The taste was similar to the aroma with more caramel, malts, pine and grapefruit. It had a medium body with decent carbonation. Not bad.
January 25, 2017 - on tap at Gerst. Clear amber pour with nice head and lacing. Aroma and taste of malt, hops and bread/yeast. Smooth drinking and light carbonation.

I poured it from the bottle into a pint glass. It pours amber with an off-white head and lacing. The aroma is piny hops and citrus. The taste is grapefruit, bread, and some hop bitterness. It was low on carbonation. This was a decent beer.

Bottle:
Clear, deep copper with a thick, off-white head.
Caramel, pine scent.
Taste is caramel malt, earthy/leafy hop bittering.
Dry...a bit weak-bodied, but pretty good.

Clear, deep amber pour with a white head. The aroma has a heavy dose of caramel and bread with a touch of grapefruit. It has a medium body with slightly sticky texture and average carbonation. The taste is mildly bitter with a dry finish.
Aroma is pale lager yeast and mild citrus/pine. The flavor is grapefruit, mild pine needles, malts and a dryish/bitter finish.
355ml bottle. Goose Island extremely quick with the spring seasonal. It is a pretty poor vienna with an odd finishing bitterness.

Preseason Lager presents a simple formula: American-style Amber Lager + extra hops. Its simple, but it delivers. Reddish pour. West Coast ale aromatics with zesty citrus and pine. Flavor is more mellow than the aroma would have you believe. There is a bright tropical fruit character and its crisp, yet the bitterness is held back by the caramel malt. This has more fresh hops than your average Lager, and that brings a stupid smile to my face.

Aroma of some bread, caramel, and a tiny note of pine/grassy hops. Crystal clear orange amber color with a nice off white head and nice lacing. Rich sweet caramel malt up front. Sweetness is quickly eclipsed by a dry bitterness. Some pine and earthy tones, of which intensify on the finish. Finish is somewhat balanced, leaning more towards the bitter tones. Light crisp mouth feel. Interesting twist on a Vienna. I prefer the more original, but this is a nice change of pace.
